3 A fixed hollow sphere with centre \(O\) has a smooth inner surface of radius \(a\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is projected horizontally with speed \(2 \sqrt{ }(a g)\) from the lowest point of the inner surface of the sphere. The particle loses contact with the inner surface of the sphere when \(O P\) makes an angle \(\theta\) with the upward vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 394, 775, 471]]<|/det|>
4 Two smooth spheres \(P\) and \(Q\), of equal radius, have masses \(m\) and \(3 m\) respectively. They are moving in the same direction in the same straight line on a smooth horizontal table. Sphere \(P\) has speed \(u\) and collides directly with sphere \(Q\) which has speed \(k u\), where \(0<k<1\). Sphere \(P\) is brought to rest by the collision. Show that the coefficient of restitution between \(P\) and \(Q\) is \(\frac{3 k+1}{3(1-k)}\).

The point \(O\) on the axis is vertically above \(C\) and \(O C=a\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(M\) is attached to the sphere at its lowest point (see diagram). Show that the moment of inertia of the system about the axis through \(O\) is \(\frac{84}{5} M a^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 845, 914, 862]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 471, 108]]<|/det|>
9 A random sample of five metal rods produced by a machine is taken. Each rod is tested for hardness. The results, in suitable units, are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[342, 117, 656, 134]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{lllll}
524 & 526 & 520 & 523 & 530
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 863, 161]]<|/det|>
Assuming a normal distribution, calculate a \(95 \%\) confidence interval for the population mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 587, 222]]<|/det|>
Some adjustments are made to the machine. Assume that a normal distribution is still appropriate and that the population variance remains unchanged. A second random sample, this time of ten metal rods, is now taken. The results for hardness are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 230, 831, 249]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{llllllllll}
525 & 520 & 522 & 524 & 518 & 520 & 519 & 525 & 527 & 516
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 557, 290]]<|/det|>
Stating suitable hypotheses, test at the \(10 \%\) significance level whether there is any difference between the population means before and after the adjustments.
